Literature Review: The advent of mobile technology has revolutionized the way people with visual impairments interact with the world around them. As smartphones and tablets have become ubiquitous, a plethora of mobile applications (apps) have emerged as potential assistive devices for visually impaired persons (VIPs). This literature review aims to explore the impact of these apps on the daily lives of VIPs, their effectiveness in various tasks, and the challenges associated with their evaluation and implementation.The proliferation of assistive apps for VIPs has been remarkable in recent years. Csapó et al. (2015) conducted a comprehensive survey of mobile assistive technologies for the visually impaired, highlighting the diverse range of apps available for tasks such as navigation, object recognition, and text reading. Their study emphasized the potential of these apps to enhance independence and quality of life for VIPs.One of the primary advantages of mobile apps as assistive devices is their affordability and accessibility compared to traditional dedicated visual aids. Hakobyan et al. (2013) noted that smartphone-based assistive technologies offer a more cost-effective and versatile solution for VIPs, as they can perform multiple functions through a single device. This accessibility has led to increased adoption rates among VIPs, as reported by Ye et al. (2014) in their study on the use of mobile phones by visually impaired users.Navigation assistance is a crucial area where mobile apps have made significant strides. Ahmetovic et al. (2016) developed and evaluated NavCog, a smartphone-based indoor navigation system for the visually impaired. Their findings demonstrated the potential of such apps to enhance mobility and independence for VIPs in complex indoor environments. Similarly, Kacorri et al. (2017) explored the use of computer vision-based apps for assisting VIPs in outdoor navigation, highlighting the promising results in terms of increased confidence and autonomy among users.Object and text recognition apps have also shown considerable promise in assisting VIPs with daily tasks. Manduchi and Coughlan (2012) reviewed various computer vision algorithms and their applications in assistive technologies for the visually impaired. They emphasized the potential of smartphone cameras coupled with advanced image processing techniques to aid in tasks such as reading signs, identifying objects, and recognizing faces.While the potential benefits of assistive apps are evident, evaluating their real-world effectiveness presents significant challenges. Crossland et al. (2014) conducted a study on the use of smartphone apps by visually impaired users and found that while many participants reported positive experiences, there was a lack of standardized evaluation methods to assess the apps' impact on daily life. This sentiment is echoed by Bhowmick and Hazarika (2017), who emphasized the need for more rigorous scientific research to understand the visual needs of VIPs and develop appropriate evaluation criteria for assistive technologies.The heterogeneity of visual impairments and the diverse range of tasks that VIPs encounter in daily life further complicate the evaluation process. Jafri et al. (2014) highlighted this challenge in their review of computer vision-based assistive technologies for the visually impaired, noting that the effectiveness of an app can vary significantly depending on the user's specific visual condition and the context of use.Despite these challenges, several studies have attempted to evaluate the impact of assistive apps on the quality of life of VIPs. Chung et al. (2016) conducted a longitudinal study on the use of a smartphone-based visual aid system and found significant improvements in participants' ability to perform daily tasks and their overall sense of independence. However, they also noted the need for more extensive, long-term studies to fully understand the impact of these technologies.As the field of assistive apps for VIPs continues to evolve, researchers and developers face the ongoing challenge of balancing technological innovation with user-centered design. Azenkot et al. (2011) emphasized the importance of involving VIPs in the design process to ensure that apps meet their specific needs and preferences. This participatory approach to design has the potential to enhance the usability and effectiveness of assistive apps.In conclusion, mobile apps have emerged as promising assistive devices for visually impaired persons, offering affordable, versatile, and accessible solutions for a wide range of visual tasks. While initial feedback from users has been largely positive, there is a clear need for more rigorous scientific evaluation of these apps' real-world benefits. Future research should focus on developing standardized evaluation methods, addressing the heterogeneity of visual impairments and tasks, and involving VIPs in the design and assessment process. As technology continues to advance, the potential for mobile apps to significantly improve the lives of visually impaired individuals remains high, but realizing this potential will require ongoing collaboration between researchers, developers, and the visually impaired community.
